Dead by Daylight wurde erstmalig im Juni des Jahres 2016 veröffentlicht. Das Spiel wurde schnell als die Mutter der asynchronen Multiplayer Spiele bezeichnet. Das Spiel ist schnell zusammengefasst ein Team aus vier Spielern versucht als "Überlebende", einem einzelnen Spieler, welcher als "Killer" bezeichnet wird zu entkommen. Die "Überlebenden", welche in der Third-Person spielen, müssen fünf Generatoren reparieren, welche die Ausgänge der wenig abwechslungsreichen Maps mit Strom versorgt. Der "Killer", welcher in der First-Person spielt, muss die Überlebenden erst mit zwei Treffern seiner Machete, Messer, Katana (Hieb, Stich oder Schlagwaffe hier einfügen) niederschlagen und dann auf Haken hängen um sie zu opfern. Das Opfer hat ungefähr zwei Minuten Zeit sich von hilfsbereiten Teamkollegen retten zu lassen oder selbst zu fliehen, was aufgrund der Erfolgschance von 5% keine Alternative ist. Es gibt drei Phasen dieser Opferung: 1. Man hängt dumm herum und beobachtet was das Team tut, 2. Der Balken ist zur Hälfte abgelaufen und man muss wie wild die Space Taste hämmern um nicht von überdimensionierten Spinnenbeinen aufgespießt zu werden, 3. Der Balken Ist abgelaufen und man wird aufgespießt ... Tod! Wenn man drei mal aufgehängt wir ist man automatisch Tod, egal wie voll der Balken noch ist. Die "Überlebenden" können nichts gegen den "Killer" tun sie können sich nur verstecken. Es gibt verschieden spielbare Charaktere jeder Charakter hat einzigartige Perks welche den "Überlebenden" das überleben leichter machen (tun sie nicht) und den "Killern" das jagen erleichtert. Zusätzlich hat jeder Killer noch eine Fähigkeit die in einzigartig macht, zum Beispiel kann sich der Geist tarnen, die Krankenschwester sich teleportieren und was der Fallensteller kann muss ich wohl nicht erklären. Unter den Charakteren findet man durch die zahlreichen Lizenzen jede Menge altbekannte Horrorfilmcharaktere wie Michael Myers, Freddy Krueger oder Leatherface. Wer wert darauf legt kann sich solche Charaktere durch die zahlreichen DLCs kaufen. Das Spiel hat extreme Balancing Probleme, der "Killer" hat normalerweise ein leichtes Spiel, das wird noch dadurch verstärkt das man durch das bescheuerte Matchmaking meist gegen "Killer" spielt die 200+ Spielzeit haben, zusätzlich hängen auf der Karte viel zu viele Haken herum sodass das herauswinden eine unnütze Funktion ist. Wer als Killer spielen möchte, weil die ganze Sterberei als "Überlebender langweilig geworden ist der hat mit absurd langen Wartezeiten zu kämpfen und wenn man in ein Spiel kommt so nach 40-120 min Wartezeit kann man auch keinen Spaß haben, weil man keine Übung hat, wie auch wenn man so gut wie nie eine Lobby mit vier Überlebenden vollkriegt? Zudem hat das Spiel eine grauenhafte Community welche meist hackt was das Zeug hält, extrem arrogant und elitär auftritt und Kein Verständnis für die Fehler von Neulingen zeigen. Das Spiel kann mit Freunden Spaß machen aber so lange das Balancing so grauenvoll ist kann ich es niemanden empfehlen. Immerhin ist das Entwicklerstudio mit vielen Content Updates und Patches sehr aktiv, vielleicht besteht noch Hoffnung.

Un compañero ideal para los desayunos y meriendas, con mucho sabor e ideales para comer a toda hora!

Hoy te mostramos lo fácil y simple que es preparar Chipa casero, también conocido como Chipá o Chipacitos.
Unos pancitos de queso a base de Fécula de Mandioca (o almidón de yuca) suaves y sabrosos para comer a toda hora!!
Los quesos que utilizamos nosotros son dos variedades de buen sabor, uno de pasta dura (Sardo) y otro de pasta semi-blanda (Pategras o Mar del Plata). Se puede utilizar cualquier queso, lo importante es que sea bien sabroso y no muy blando.
Conseguí
Fécula de Mandioca 300 Gr.
Manteca (Mantequilla) 50 Gr.
Leche 50 Ml.
Jugo de Naranja 50 Ml.
Huevo 2 u.
Sal 1 cdita.
Queso Duro (Sardo) 50 Gr.
Queso Semiduro (Pategras) 150 Gr.
Obtenés 20 Chipas para disfrutar en cualquier momento del día y como compañero inseparable del mate!!
Cociná
Cortar los quesos en cubos chicos, también se pueden rallar.
Colocar en un bowl la fécula, sal, leche, juego de naranja y los huevos.
El juego de naranja es opcional, se puede reemplazar por más leche.
Batir a penas para desligar los huevos y agregar la manteca pomada (blanda).
Incorporar bien todos los ingredientes y agregar los quesos.
Utilizar las manos para lograr una masa bien integrada y pareja.
Tomar trozos de masa y formar bolitas con las manos.
Colocarlas sobre una fuente para horno, con una buena distancia entre cada uno y de forma pareja.
Hornear durante 15 minutos a temperatura media-alta (200ºC), en horno precalentado.

Disfrutarlos aún tibios!!

Sensacional

The Game: I'll save you the TL;DR and tell you up front, in a broad sense:

Gameplay overall: 4/10 Fun at first, gets dull very quickly
Survivor gameplay: 5/10 The most consistently fun, still rather dull
Killer gameplay: 2/10 Dull at it's best, excruciatingly frustrating at it's worst.
Devs: 1/10 An embarrassment to game developers everywhere, and public figures representing a product in general.

Spare yourself the pain and disappointment, and protect your internet privacy and location privacy, and do NOT play this game. This game is not as fun as it may seem. It is successful almost exclusively because it has virtually no competition as solid as itself, and as such, the game is quite lacklustre.

If you still crave this genre, and many of us do, check out "VHS" by Hellbent Games; a team of devs working hard on a free-to-play 4v1 asymmetrical game just like Dead by Daylight, except with personality, fun, and collectively tens of thousands of hours by the devs themselves in their beta-build.

The Review:


Is this game fun? For the first few tens of hours for killer, moderately. For survivor, most of the time but very inconsistently.

This game is a testament to understanding the game design concept of feel versus efficiency. By that I mean, according to the developers, the numbers in relation to the balancing of each killer's abilities (known as Powers) and tools that can aid or transform these abilities (known as Addons) are tailored to an experience that should net you on average a draw. They have directly admitted their matchmaking system, as it currently stands, is nearly 100% accurate at determining which matches a player is likely to succeed within, and given those circumstances, each killer is balanced for the average rating of what is considered to be a draw. That itself is a design failure, in my opinion, as balancing should give every player ample opportunity to achieve a total victory, given they reach the appropriate level of skill and/or knowledge. I'll use sports as an example (a community in-joke I'll explain later), Soccer, or Football as it is also called, does not include rules and/or strategies that are designed to consistently reach a draw. It is only in the context of perfectly matched teams where draws are a high possibility. If skills are equally met, that is, but each player's potential skill isn't limited to identically match every other player. They themselves have the ability to train skills to become better and better to increase their chances of victory. And I am aware that sports versus video games is not an equal match up as there is far more design control over video games and their mathematical properties. 

However, rather recently, the community has been stricken by a competitive "skill-based matchmaking" system implemented by the developers themselves. That is what I have explained above. This system is designed for a context of mathematical perfection, and/or consistency. That being said, the developers themselves have stated that it only considers victories (escaping as a survivor, killing survivors as a killer), Defeats (Dying as a survivor, survivors escaping your killer), and time spent in a match (an ambiguous at best variable). This system is a total failure because 1. these three variables are a fraction of the design of this game's game-play loop and as such reward virtually nothing significant. 2. For the almost 6 years this game has been live, the community has ambiguously agreed in what circumstances skill is determined, and instead of listening to their community, the developers lazily created their own system that does very little work to reward and to punish. 3. Because the matchmaking only considers victories, losses, and time spent in a match, success and failure do not take into account the means of their achieving. Why is this an issue? Because in Dead by Daylight (DBD per the community) there are perks, addons, chase-length, altruism (team-play), objective time, use of power, use of addons, use of specific loops, survivor items, survivor offerings, killer offerings, and more, that all can completely change one's gameplay in an instant when used.

For example, a survivor may hide literally the entire match while their team does all the work on the objective and with saving each other. However, if the objective is completed and the hiding survivor manages to escape while the rest die: the system considers the survivor who did nothing a more valuable and skilled player than the ones who actually played the video game.

Furthermore, if a killer brings an addon, let's say Huntress brings her strong addon that allows her to instantly knockdown survivors with a single hatchet (whereas it takes two, and likely a chase), and kills every survivor within the first 3 minutes of a match (avg. length = approx. 10 mins), and another killer, let's say The Twins spend all match at maximum effort, and very nearly kills all survivors while going out of their way to play without deliberately tarnishing the survivor experience, but the survivors all eventually escape, the matchmaking system will consider the Huntress player far more valuable and succesful than the Twins player.

Essentially, there are a massive multitude of variables that can make or break a single action, many of which the game actually wants you to do with a point incentive (used to improve characters), and yet it is only the result that is taken into account. This creates an entirely new bizarre and frustrating match up, where only the strongest possible meta builds are favoured. No fun, meme, or creativity is possible when you play at high mmr-rating; only the meta, which creates a stale and boringly repetitive meta. For survivors you reach a point where you only ever face the same 3 or four killers (of almost 30) because those are the only killer powers capable of lasting against the survivor meta. And for killer, you only ever play against a perfectly coordinated team of friends with the best perks, looping skills, and items.

If I could sum it up; balancing to reach an average of draws is so incredibly boring and frustrating because it basically means you consistently win until you consistently lose, or infrequently draw. It is a horrible system, the developers have said themselves the game wasn't intended to be competitive, and yet they implement a competitive matchmaking system. The community, almost unanimously (which is saying something for this community) despises the new system. Yet, the developers very rarely listen to and genuinely consider player feedback.

- The 50 percentile of killer designs are too weak to be used most of the time
- While the 40 percentile is too boring to make players interested in playing them, or even just disappoint players
- And the remaining 10% best of the best killers can feel creatively restricting and unsatisfying most of the time as there is a sense of obligation to play them, whether you are interested in them or not
- Skill-based matchmaking is making the game literally bleed players (the playerbase, usually fairly consistent) has gone down steadily 50% from November 2021, I believe a few months after the introduction of SBMM, and hasn't seen a net positive increase since then, even during the release of a "The Ring" licensed chapter, and licensed chapters have always created a net positive interest in the game (A Nightmare on Elm Street, Texas Chainsaw Massacre, SAW, Resident Evil, Silent Hill, Stranger Things, etc.)

How are the developers?: Obnoxious and patronising business persons.

Behaviour interactive, the developers of this game, are tone-deaf, arrogant, ignorant, oblivious, and short-sighted. Frequently ignoring feedback, blaming players, implementing mind-boggling changes, adding more to already horrible game code infrastructure, talking down to players, misrepresenting sports, misrepresenting player complaints, favouriting positive feedback, banning negative feedback/criticism.
